To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

6 Junij
1591
. M
r
Bodeley to my L.
By Collonel Methkerkes brother./

May it please yo
r
good L. It is nowe de-
termined, that
e towne of Groeninghen
shall be presently attempted: for whiche
e
troupes are risen, and marching already.
Their artillerie is embarcked and sent
away before. But whether they will use
e
benefit of her Hig
nes
letters, w
ch
were written
so long sins, and I have still in my custody,
I can not readily conjecture. But being often
required by
e Councels letters to repaire
unto them, I thinke they have a meaning,
when no other meanes will serve their turne,
to use
e countenance of her Ma
tie
. If it
come to that passe, I will advise upon
e
best for her Hignes contentac
o
n. For I have
seene by good tokens, that Count William is
afraid to be sette byside
e government, if
the towne be reduced by her Ma
ties
autoritie
for w
ch
I thinke he will endevor to prevaile
an other way. The party whiche
I imploied about
e recoverie of those papers
and bookes, that came out of spaine, hath
spedde of his purpose, and hath all already
in his custody. Because his dwelling is in
Amsterdam, and my way into Frise, (where
I thinke within these two daies to meete
e
Councell) is by Amsterdam, I will take the
writinges to my self, and convey them from
thens by
e speediest meanes that I can finde.
The bearer herof is
e brother of
Cap
t
Methekerke,
at was slaine of late in the
siege of Deventer. He comes an humble suto
r
to yo
r
L. to obtene his brothers place, which

in the judgement of those, that have seene the
proofe of his valiant cariage, he will deserve in
all respectes aswell as his brother. Whiche being
notified unto me, by those that knowe his suffi-
ciencie, I could not but report it, and recom-
mend him effectually to yo
r
L. favo
r
.
This day I have written a letter to yo
r
L. by
an Englishe souldier, whiche came hither from
Brussels, where, as he saieth, he had bin pri-
soner 5 weekes. His comming to me was
for a letter to yo
r
L. or to some other of my
LL. of
e Councel, to
e ende he might be
heard in disclosing of
a practise among the
fugitives
of
Brussels
, for
e setting a fire
of her Ma
ties
shippes.

I have learned by enquirie, that he caried

greater summe, then a co
m

a man of simple q

litie and shewe should

well
gotten, unles he were hired to a

muche about him, his answear was, that S
r

at
e campe, w
t
sundrie other vaine and
unpro
fitable
bable

ch
I thought very re-
quisit to impart unto yo
r
L. because it ca-
rieth suspicion of some thing els intended,
then
e service he professeth. Notw
t
-
standing many constant reportes,
at we have
had in these contreis,
at
e mutins of Diest

at

nt
